Description:
An action footer is a user interface (UI) component that provides common actions in the form of pre-arranged buttons and hyperlinks, as well as dividers to segment groups of actions. Action footers are the lowest level of content within a container and can be used within the layout of a page to divide and organize content in meaningful ways. They provide the users with actions that can be associated with the content that lives within the container.
 This solution includes the following components: Standard Action Footer
- Single Start Action
- Centered Action Footer
- Multiple Start and End Actions
Centerted Action Footer
- Single  Action
- Multiple Actions
Block Action Footer
- Single  Action
- Multiple Actions
Contact Information:
David Gustafson, Senior Software Testing Engineer, David_Gustafson@epam.com
Frederick Pollnitz, Sr. User Experience Designer, C_pollnitz.frederick@cerner.com
Evaluation Methods:
During testing, Cerner Corporation used a software-based testing process and consolidated keyboard testing; screen reader testing using JAWS, screen reader menu shortcuts where applicable; system controls testing using Sticky Keys, Filter, High Contrast; keyboard commands; color testing using The Paciello Group's color analyzer. Web tools, when applicable, consist of WAVE, Cerner A11Y Tool, aXe, SiteImprove, ANDI code checkers and NoCoffee disability simulator.

Applicable standards and guidelines include WCAG 2.1 Levels A and AA; Section 508 Chapters 3, 5, and 6. Chapter 4, Hardware, is not applicable to this product. European standards (EN 301 549) include Chapters 4, 11, and 12. WCAG 2.1 covers Chapter 9 of EN 301 549. Chapters 5-8, 10, and 13 do not apply.

Criteria text:
1.1.1 Non-text Content: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below. (Level A) (Edited for brevity)
Controls, Input: If non-text content is a control or accepts user input, then it has a name that describes its purpose. 
Time-Based Media: If non-text content is time-based media, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content. 
Test: If non-text content is a test or exercise that would be invalid if presented in text, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
Sensory: If non-text content is primarily intended to create a specific sensory experience, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
CAPTCHA: If the purpose of non-text content is to confirm that content is being accessed by a person rather than a computer, then text alternatives that identify and describe the purpose of the non-text content are provided, and alternative forms of CAPTCHA using output modes for different types of sensory perception are provided to accommodate different disabilities.
Decoration, Formatting, Invisible: If non-text content is pure decoration, is used only for visual formatting, or is not presented to users, then it is implemented in a way that it can be ignored by assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 1.1.1 Non-text Content: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below. (Level A)  Controls, Input: If non-text content is a control or accepts user
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would not be applicable to this criterion. 

Terra provides implementing team(s) the ability to include images which would need alternative content.

Implementing team(s) must ensure appropriate alternate content is added to meaningful content.

Criteria text:
1.2.1 Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded): For prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such: (Level A)

Prerecorded Audio-only: An alternative for time-based media is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded audio-only content.

Prerecorded Video-only: Either an alternative for time-based media or an audio track is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded video-only content.
Truncated Criteria: 1.2.1 Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded): For prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such: (Level A)  Prerecorded
Explanation:
Product does not contain media. 

The implementing team must ensure this criterion is met if media is added.

Criteria text: 1.2.2 Captions (Prerecorded): Captions are provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.
Truncated Criteria: 1.2.2 Captions (Prerecorded): Captions are provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.
Explanation:
Product does not contain media. 

The implementing team must ensure this criterion is met if media is added.

Criteria text: 1.2.3 Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded): An alternative for time-based media or audio description of the prerecorded video content is provided for synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.
Truncated Criteria: 1.2.3 Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded): An alternative for time-based media or audio description of the prerecorded video content is provided for synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is cle
Explanation:
Product does not contain media. 

The implementing team must ensure this criterion is met if media is added.

Criteria text: 1.3.1 Info and Relationships: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.
Truncated Criteria: 1.3.1 Info and Relationships: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that can hold interactive content. It does not create any visual relationships that must be conveyed programmatically for users to understand or use the component.

Terra does provide the ability to include interactive elements within the Action Footer.

Implementing team(s) must ensure that any meaningful context that is provided visually is also programmatically determined.

Criteria text: 1.3.2 Meaningful Sequence: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined.
Truncated Criteria: 1.3.2 Meaningful Sequence: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would support meaningful sequence of content. The visual presentation of the native container does not convey any meaningful order. Content within the Action Footer would be read in the order of the code.

Terra provides implementing teams the ability to add content to the Action Footer in whatever order they need for a meaningful sequence. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure any content added to Terra Action Footer is added in a way that supports the meaningful sequenece of the reading order.

Criteria text: 1.3.3 Sensory Characteristics: Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics of components such as shape, size, visual location, orientation, or sound.
Truncated Criteria: 1.3.3 Sensory Characteristics: Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics of components such as shape, size, visual location, orientation, or sound.
Explanation:
Terra does not provide any instructions within the UI. 

Implementing team(s) must review their content to ensure sensory characteristics are not included within any instructions. For example:
"Click on the green pencil" would require users to have both perception of color and sight.

"Listen for the beep" would require a user to hear.

"Select the star at the top of the page" would require the user to see the star and know where at the top to find it.

Criteria text:
1.4.1 Use of Color: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element. (Level A)

Note: This success criterion addresses color perception specifically. Other forms of perception are covered in Guideline 1.3 including programmatic access to color and other visual presentation coding.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.1 Use of Color: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element. (Level A)  Note: This success criterion addresses color perception specifically.
Explanation:
Terra components do rely on color alone to convey information.

Implementing team(s) must ensure color is not the only method used to convey information to the user. Instead, use both color and a shape or text.

Criteria text:
1.4.2 Audio Control: If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently from the overall system volume level. (Level A)

Note: Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all content on the Web page (whether or not it is used to meet other success criteria) must meet this success criterion.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.2 Audio Control: If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently from the overall system volume
Explanation:
No audio plays upon opening screens in product.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if media is added to the product.

Criteria text: 2.1.1 Keyboard: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints. (Level A)
Truncated Criteria: 2.1.1 Keyboard: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movemen
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer does not receive keyboard focus and is not actionable by itself.

Terra Action Footer supports including interactive buttons and links within it.

Implementing team(s) must ensure that all interactable elements can receive focus, be interacted with, and able to be acted upon.

Criteria text:
2.1.2 No Keyboard Trap: If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of the page using a keyboard interface, then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface, and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab keys or other standard exit methods, the user is advised of the method for moving focus away. (Level A)

Note: Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all content on the Web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion.
Truncated Criteria: 2.1.2 No Keyboard Trap: If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of the page using a keyboard interface, then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface, and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab keys
Explanation:
User is able to focus in and out of Terra Action Footer without encountering a keyboard trap when interactive elements are used within it.

Implementing team(s) must ensure no keyboard traps are introduced into code.

Criteria text: 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts: If a keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true: Turn off A mechanism is available to turn the shortcut off; Remap A mechanism is available to remap the shortcut to use one or more non-printable keyboard characters (e.g. Ctrl, Alt, etc); Active only on focus The keyboard shortcut for a user interface component is only active when that component has focus.
Truncated Criteria: 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts: If a keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true: Turn off A mechanism i
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer does not have any character-key (single-letter) shortcuts.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met and not implement a single key shortcut without the ability to turn off, remap the key, or be available only when a component has focus.

Criteria text:
2.2.1 Timing Adjustable: For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true: (Level A) (Edited for brevity)
Turn off: The user is allowed to turn off the time limit before encountering it; or Adjust: The user is allowed to adjust the time limit before encountering it over a wide range that is at least ten times the length of the default setting; or Extend: The user is warned before time expires and given at least 20 seconds to extend the time limit with a simple action (for example, "press the space bar"), and the user is allowed to extend the time limit at least ten times; or Real-time Exception: The time limit is a required part of a real-time event (for example, an auction), and no alternative to the time limit is possible; or Essential Exception: The time limit is essential and extending it would invalidate the activity; or 20 Hour Exception: The time limit is longer than 20 hours.
Truncated Criteria: 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable: For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true: (Level A)  Turn off: The user is allowed to turn off the time limit before encountering it; or  Adjust: The user is allowed to adjust the
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that is not dependent upon timing.

Implementing team(s) must ensure users can turn off, adjust, or extend any time limit unless the limit meets the requirement of one of the exceptions.

Criteria text: 2.2.2 Pause, Stop, Hide: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true: (Level A) Moving, blinking, scrolling: For any moving, blinking or scrolling information that (1) starts automatically, (2) lasts more than five seconds, and (3) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it unless the movement, blinking, or scrolling is part of an activity where it is essential; and Auto-updating: For any auto-updating information that (1) starts automatically and (2) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it or to control the frequency of the update unless the auto-updating is part of an activity where it is essential.
Truncated Criteria: 2.2.2 Pause, Stop, Hide: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true: (Level A)  Moving, blinking, scrolling: For any moving, blinking or scrolling information that (1) starts automatically, (2) lasts
Explanation:
Nothing autoplays or moves in application.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if media is added to the product.

Criteria text:
2.3.1 Three Flashes or Below Threshold: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds. (Level A)

Note: Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all content on the Web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion.
Truncated Criteria: 2.3.1 Three Flashes or Below Threshold: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds. (Level A)  Note: Since any content that does not
Explanation:
Product contains no flashing or flickering that would cause seizures or migraines.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if media is added to the product.

Criteria text: 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple Web pages.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple Web pages.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a component that would not generally have or need bypass blocks.

Implementing team(s) must ensure methods are employed to meet this criterion when required.

Criteria text: 2.4.2 Page Titled: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.2 Page Titled: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is independent of the whole page.

Implementing team(s) must ensure pages have the appropriate page title defined in the HTML head of the page as well as modals and iframes.

Criteria text: 2.4.3 Focus Order: If a Web page can be navigated sequentially and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.3 Focus Order: If a Web page can be navigated sequentially and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container and does not receive focus itself.

Terra supports the ability to include interactive components within Action Footer  and will received focus in order of the code. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure the focus order is expected and preserves page meaning. Implementing team(s) must also ensure not to implement a tab index value greater than zero.

Criteria text: 2.4.4 Link Purpose (In Context): The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context, except where the purpose of the link would be ambiguous to users in general.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.4 Link Purpose (In Context): The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context, except where the purpose of the link would be ambiguous to users in
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would not be applicable to this criterion. Links used within the Action Footer must meet this requirement. 

Terra Action Footer provides the ability for implementing team(s) to create links  unique and descriptive within the Action Footer. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure that the purpose of links are visually and programmatically available.

Criteria text:
2.5.1 Pointer Gestures: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a single pointer without a path-based gesture, unless a multipoint or path-based gesture is essential. NOTE
This requirement applies to web content that interprets pointer actions (i.e. this does not apply to actions that are required to operate the user agent or assistive technology).
Truncated Criteria: 2.5.1 Pointer Gestures: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a single pointer without a path-based gesture, unless a multipoint or path-based gesture is essential. NOTE This requirement appl
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a non interactable container. 

Terra provides the ability to add interactable content to Terra Action Footer. 

Implementing teams must ensure any multipoint or path based gestures can be  operated without a path-based gesture.

Criteria text: 2.5.2 Pointer Cancellation: For functionality that can be operated using a single pointer, at least one of the following is true: No Down-Event The down-event of the pointer is not used to execute any part of the function; Abort or Undo Completion of the function is on the up-event, and a mechanism is available to abort the function before completion or to undo the function after completion; Up Reversal The up-event reverses any outcome of the preceding down-event; Essential Completing the function on the down-event is essential. NOTE: Functions that emulate a keyboard or numeric keypad key press are considered essential. NOTE: This requirement applies to web content that interprets pointer actions (i.e. this does not apply to actions that are required to operate the user agent or assistive technology).
Truncated Criteria: 2.5.2 Pointer Cancellation: For functionality that can be operated using a single pointer, at least one of the following is true: No Down-Event The down-event of the pointer is not used to execute any part of the function; Abort or Undo Completion of
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would not be applicable to this criterion because it does not accept input itself. 

Terra provides the ability to add interatable elements to the container. Any interactable elements used within the Action Footer would be required to meet this criterion.

Implementing team(s) must ensure that actions are not activated by the down action allowing the user to cancel interactions.

Criteria text: 2.5.3 Label in Name: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually. NOTE: A best practice is to have the text of the label at the start of the name.
Truncated Criteria: 2.5.3 Label in Name: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually. NOTE: A best practice is to have the text of the label at the start of the name.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a module that contains other components. It does not have a label.

Terra provides the ability for implementing team(s) to add interactive content inside the Action Footer with a visual and programmatic label to components.

Implementing team(s) must ensure the programmatic label matches the visual label when interactable elements are included with this component.

Criteria text: 2.5.4 Motion Actuation: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components and responding to the motion can be disabled to prevent accidental actuation, except when: Supported Interface The motion is used to operate functionality through an accessibility supported interface; Essential The motion is essential for the function and doing so would invalidate the activity.
Truncated Criteria: 2.5.4 Motion Actuation: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components and responding to the motion can be disabled to prevent accidental actuation, except when: Supported Interfac
Explanation:
Terra does not provide any motion based functionality. 

If motion based functionality is implemented, implementing team(s) would be responsible to ensure this requirement is met.

Criteria text: 3.1.1 Language of Page: The default human language of each Web page can be programmatically determined.
Truncated Criteria: 3.1.1 Language of Page: The default human language of each Web page can be programmatically determined.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is independent of language.

Implementing team(s) must ensure the appropriate LANG attribute value is set to ensure language of the page can be programmatically determined.

Criteria text: 3.2.1 On Focus: When any component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context.
Truncated Criteria: 3.2.1 On Focus: When any component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container of other components, and does not initiate a change of context (or anything unexpected).

Implementing team(s) must ensure no unexpected change of context happens when interactive elements receive focus.

Criteria text: 3.2.2 On Input: Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component.
Truncated Criteria: 3.2.2 On Input: Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would not be applicable to this criterion because it is not an input. Contents within the Action Footer must meet this requirement. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure no change of context happens when interactive elements are incorporated into the product.

Criteria text: 3.3.1 Error Identification: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.
Truncated Criteria: 3.3.1 Error Identification: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container and therefore would never cause errors. Contents within the Action Footer must meet this requirement. 

Terra provides the ability to identify errors within forms.

Implementing team(s) must ensure error identification is provided when implementing forms.

Criteria text: 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.
Truncated Criteria: 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that does not require input.  

Terra provides the ability to include interactive content within the Action Footer.

Implementing team(s) must ensure labels and instructions are provided when needed to ensure users know what is expected.

Criteria text: 4.1.1 Parsing: In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, elements do not contain duplicate attributes, and any IDs are unique, except where the specifications allow these features.
Truncated Criteria: 4.1.1 Parsing: In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, elements do not contain duplicate attributes, and any IDs are unique, except where the spe
Explanation: Terra components are tested and validated before release to ensure proper parsing of code.

Criteria text: 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value: For all user interface components (including but not limited to: form elements, links and components generated by scripts), the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set by the user can be programmatically set; and notification of changes to these items is available to user agents, including assistive technologies.
Truncated Criteria: 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value: For all user interface components (including but not limited to: form elements, links and components generated by scripts), the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set
Explanation:
Name, Role, and Value does not apply to Terra Action Footer because it is not an actionable element.

Terra provides the ability to add content within action footer.
 
Implementing team(s) must ensure that any content inside Action Footer meets this criterion.

Criteria text: Criteria
1.2.4 Captions (Live): Captions are provided for all live audio content in synchronized media.
Truncated Criteria: 1.2.4 Captions (Live): Captions are provided for all live audio content in synchronized media.
Explanation:
Product does not contain media. 

The implementing team must ensure this criterion is met if media is added.

Criteria text: 1.2.5 Audio Description (Prerecorded): Audio description is provided for all prerecorded video content in synchronized media.
Truncated Criteria: 1.2.5 Audio Description (Prerecorded): Audio description is provided for all prerecorded video content in synchronized media.
Explanation:
Product does not contain media. 

The implementing team must ensure this criterion is met if media is added.

Criteria text: 1.3.4 Orientation: Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation, such as portrait or landscape, unless a specific display orientation is essential. NOTE Examples where a particular display orientation may be essential are a bank check, a piano application, slides for a projector or television, or virtual reality content where binary display orientation is not applicable.
Truncated Criteria: 1.3.4 Orientation: Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation, such as portrait or landscape, unless a specific display orientation is essential. NOTE Examples where a particular display orientation may be essent
Explanation:
Terra components operate independent of orientation.

Implementing team(s) must ensure all products meet this requirement.

Criteria text: 1.3.5 Identify Input Purpose: The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be programmatically determined when: The input field serves a purpose identified in the Input Purposes for User Interface Components section; and The content is implemented using technologies with support for identifying the expected meaning for form input data.
Truncated Criteria: 1.3.5 Identify Input Purpose: The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be programmatically determined when: The input field serves a purpose identified in the Input Purposes for User Interface Components section; and
Explanation: Terra Action Footer is a container not an input.

Criteria text:
1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum): The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for the following: (Level AA)

Large Text: Large-scale text and images of large-scale text have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1;

Incidental: Text or images of text that are part of an inactive user interface component, that are pure decoration, that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement.

Logotypes: Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no minimum contrast requirement.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum): The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for the following: (Level AA)  Large Text: Large-scale text and images of large-scale text have a contrast ratio of at least 3
Explanation:
Default content within Terra Action meets the appropriate contrast ratios. 

Terra Action Footer provides the ability to include other actionable elements within Action Footer.

Implementing team(s) must ensure any content used within Terra Action Footer meets the proper contrast ratios for this criterion to be met.

Criteria text: 1.4.4 Resize text: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.4 Resize text: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer supports resizing and zooming without loss of information or function.

Implementing team(s) must ensure content other than captions and images of text can be up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.

Truncated Criteria: 1.4.5 Images of Text: If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, text is used to convey information rather than images of text except for the following: (Level AA)  Customizable: The image of text can be visually customized t
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would not be applicable to this criterion because it is not an image. 

Terra provides the ability to add images within Terra Action Footer. Any images used within the Action Footer must meet this requirement. Images of text are discouraged.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met with any content used within Terra Action Footer.

Criteria text:
1.4.10 Reflow: Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for: Vertical scrolling content at a width equivalent to 320 CSS pixels;
Horizontal scrolling content at a height equivalent to 256 CSS pixels. Except for parts of the content which require two-dimensional layout for usage or meaning. NOTE Note: 320 CSS pixels is equivalent to a starting viewport width of 1280 CSS pixels wide at 400% zoom. For web content which are designed to scroll horizontally (e.g. with vertical text), the 256 CSS pixels is equivalent to a starting viewport height of 1024px at 400% zoom. NOTE Examples of content which require two-dimensional layout are images, maps, diagrams, video, games, presentations, data tables, and interfaces where it is necessary to keep toolbars in view while manipulating content.
Truncated Criteria:
1.4.10 Reflow: Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for: Vertical scrolling content at a width equivalent to 320 CSS pixels;
Horizontal scrolling content at a height
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer supports reflow when the viewport is resized to 320x256 px without loss of information or function.

Implementing team(s) must ensure content placed within Action Footer meets this criterion.

Criteria text: 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast: The visual presentation of the following have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent color(s): User Interface Components Visual information required to identify user interface components and states, except for inactive components or where the appearance of the component is determined by the user agent and not modified by the author; Graphical Objects Parts of graphics required to understand the content, except when a particular presentation of graphics is essential to the information being conveyed.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.11 Non-Text Contrast: The visual presentation of the following have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent color(s): User Interface Components Visual information required to identify user interface components and states, except for ina
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that does not have non-text-content that conveys information to the user. The border is not required for users to understand the content it contains. 

Terra provides the ability to non-text elements within the Terra Action Footer. Any non-text content used within the Action Footer must meet this requirement.

Implementing team(s) must ensure that any non-text content that conveys meaning to the user meet the 3:1 contrast ratio.

Criteria text: 1.4.12 Text Spacing: In content implemented using markup languages that support the following text style properties, no loss of content or functionality occurs by setting all of the following and by changing no other style property: Line height (line spacing) to at least 1.5 times the font size; Spacing following paragraphs to at least 2 times the font size; Letter spacing (tracking) to at least 0.12 times the font size; Word spacing to at least 0.16 times the font size. Exception: Human languages and scripts that do not make use of one or more of these text style properties in written text can conform using only the properties that exist for that combination of language and script.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.12 Text Spacing: In content implemented using markup languages that support the following text style properties, no loss of content or functionality occurs by setting all of the following and by changing no other style property: Line height (line
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer supports altering multiple CSS attributes without loss of function or information.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text:
1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus: Where receiving and then removing pointer hover or keyboard focus triggers additional content to become visible and then hidden, the following are true: Dismissable A mechanism is available to dismiss the additional content without moving pointer hover or keyboard focus, unless the additional content communicates an input error or does not obscure or replace other content; Hoverable If pointer hover can trigger the additional content, then the pointer can be moved over the additional content without the additional content disappearing; Persistent The additional content remains visible until the hover or focus trigger is removed, the user dismisses it, or its information is no longer valid.
Exception: The visual presentation of the additional content is controlled by the user agent and is not modified by the author. NOTE Examples of additional content controlled by the user agent include browser tooltips created through use of the HTML title attribute. NOTE Custom tooltips, sub-menus, and other nonmodal popups that display on hover and focus are examples of additional content covered by this criterion.
Truncated Criteria: 1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus: Where receiving and then removing pointer hover or keyboard focus triggers additional content to become visible and then hidden, the following are true: Dismissable A mechanism is available to dismiss the additional
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container of other components. The Action footer itself does not have a hover. 

Terra provides the ability on add content to action footer. Any content used within Action Footer may potentially have content on hover or focus.

Implementing team(s) must ensure that any content on hover or focus, other than the tool tip from the TITLE attribute, meets this criterion.

Criteria text: 2.4.5 Multiple Ways: More than one way is available to locate a Web page within a set of Web pages except where the Web Page is the result of, or a step in, a process.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.5 Multiple Ways: More than one way is available to locate a Web page within a set of Web pages except where the Web Page is the result of, or a step in, a process.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is independent of the whole page.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 2.4.6 Headings and Labels: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.6 Headings and Labels: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that does not have a label or heading. Terra Action Footer is a container that can include actionable components which must meet this requirement if included.

Terra Action Footer provides the ability for teams to create a meaningful label.

Implementing team(s) must ensure headings and labels use text that appropriately describes the topic or purpose it represents.

Criteria text: 2.4.7 Focus Visible: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.
Truncated Criteria: 2.4.7 Focus Visible: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.
Explanation:
Terra Action footer is a container and does not receive focus itself. 

Terra supports including interactive components  within Action Footer.

Implementing team(s) must ensure visible focus is maintained on interactive elements used within the Terra Action Footer.

Criteria text: 3.1.2 Language of Parts: The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding text.
Truncated Criteria: 3.1.2 Language of Parts: The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the verna
Explanation:
Terra supports the ability for the component to have a separate language attribute. If controls are labeled with a differing language of the page being used, Terra supports the ability to accurately reflect the correct language of the content.

Implementing team(s) must ensure the appropriate LANG attribute value is applied, if/where applicable, to ensure any content not of the same language of the page can be programmatically understood as the correct language.

Criteria text: 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation: Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple Web pages within a set of Web pages occur in the same relative order each time they are repeated, unless a change is initiated by the user.
Truncated Criteria: 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation: Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple Web pages within a set of Web pages occur in the same relative order each time they are repeated, unless a change is initiated by the user.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is not navigation and it is independent of the whole page.

Implementing team(s) must ensure when navigation is used, that it remains consistent from page to page.

Criteria text: 3.2.4 Consistent Identification: Components that have the same functionality within a set of Web pages are identified consistently.
Truncated Criteria: 3.2.4 Consistent Identification: Components that have the same functionality within a set of Web pages are identified consistently.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is only a container that does not have any inherent functionality. 

Terra supports the ability to add buttons and links within the Action Footer.

Implementing team(s) must ensure to consistently identify elements within the Action Footer used for the same functionality.

Criteria text: 3.3.3 Error Suggestion: If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the content.
Truncated Criteria: 3.3.3 Error Suggestion: If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the content.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that would not be applicable to this criterion. Contents within the Action Footer must meet this requirement. 

Terra provides the ability to include error suggestion when forms are validated.

Implementing team(s) must ensure error suggestion is provided when implementing forms.

Criteria text:
3.3.4 Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data): For Web pages that cause legal commitments or financial transactions for the user to occur, that modify or delete user-controllable data in data storage systems, or that submit user test responses, at least one of the following is true: (Level AA)

Reversible: Submissions are reversible.

Checked: Data entered by the user is checked for input errors and the user is provided an opportunity to correct them.

Confirmed: A mechanism is available for reviewing, confirming, and correcting information before finalizing the submission.
Truncated Criteria: 3.3.4 Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data): For Web pages that cause legal commitments or financial transactions for the user to occur, that modify or delete user-controllable data in data storage systems, or that submit user test responses, at
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is a container that is independent of forms and validation. Contents within the Action Footer that drive form validation must meet this requirement. 

It is incumbent upon implementing team(s) to make sure that this requirement is met when forms are provided within a product.

Criteria text: 4.1.3 Status Messages: In content implemented using markup languages, status messages can be programmatically determined through role or properties such that they can be presented to the user by assistive technologies without receiving focus.
Truncated Criteria: 4.1.3 Status Messages: In content implemented using markup languages, status messages can be programmatically determined through role or properties such that they can be presented to the user by assistive technologies without receiving focus.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer does not have a status. There are no messages to be displayed.

Terra provides the ability for implementing team(s) to add the programmatically knowable status messages. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure any status messages are implemented correctly to ensure programmatic availability.

Criteria text: Criteria
501.1 Scope - Incorporation of WCAG 2.0 AA
Truncated Criteria: 501.1 Scope - Incorporation of WCAG 2.0 AA

Criteria text: 502 Interoperability with Assistive Technology
Truncated Criteria: 502 Interoperability with Assistive Technology

Criteria text: 502.2.1 User Control of Accessibility Features. Platform software shall provide user control over platform features that are defined in the platform documentation as accessibility features.
Truncated Criteria: 502.2.1 User Control of Accessibility Features. Platform software shall provide user control over platform features that are defined in the platform documentation as accessibility features.

Criteria text: 502.2.2 No Disruption of Accessibility Features. Software shall not disrupt platform features that are defined in the platform documentation as accessibility features.
Truncated Criteria: 502.2.2 No Disruption of Accessibility Features. Software shall not disrupt platform features that are defined in the platform documentation as accessibility features.

Criteria text: 502.3 Accessibility Services
Truncated Criteria: 502.3 Accessibility Services

Criteria text: 502.3.1 Object Information. The object role, state(s), properties, boundary, name, and description shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.1 Object Information. The object role, state(s), properties, boundary, name, and description shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.2 Modification of Object Information. States and properties that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.2 Modification of Object Information. States and properties that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.

Criteria text: 502.3.3 Row, Column, and Headers. If an object is in a data table, the occupied rows and columns, and any headers associated with those rows or columns, shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.3 Row, Column, and Headers. If an object is in a data table, the occupied rows and columns, and any headers associated with those rows or columns, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.4 Values. Any current value(s), and any set or range of allowable values associated with an object, shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.4 Values. Any current value(s), and any set or range of allowable values associated with an object, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.5 Modification of Values. Values that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.5 Modification of Values. Values that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.

Criteria text: 502.3.6 Label Relationships. Any relationship that a component has as a label for another component, or of being labeled by another component, shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.6 Label Relationships. Any relationship that a component has as a label for another component, or of being labeled by another component, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.7 Hierarchical Relationships. Any hierarchical (parent-child) relationship that a component has as a container for, or being contained by, another component shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.7 Hierarchical Relationships. Any hierarchical (parent-child) relationship that a component has as a container for, or being contained by, another component shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.8 Text. The content of text objects, text attributes, and the boundary of text rendered to the screen, shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.8 Text. The content of text objects, text attributes, and the boundary of text rendered to the screen, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.9 Modification of Text. Text that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.9 Modification of Text. Text that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.

Criteria text: 502.3.10 List of Actions. A list of all actions that can be executed on an object shall be programmatically determinable.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.10 List of Actions. A list of all actions that can be executed on an object shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 502.3.11 Actions on Objects. Applications shall allow assistive technology to programmatically execute available actions on objects.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.11 Actions on Objects. Applications shall allow assistive technology to programmatically execute available actions on objects.

Criteria text: 502.3.12 Focus Cursor. Applications shall expose information and mechanisms necessary to track focus, text insertion point, and selection attributes of user interface components.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.12 Focus Cursor. Applications shall expose information and mechanisms necessary to track focus, text insertion point, and selection attributes of user interface components.

Criteria text: 502.3.13 Modification of Focus Cursor. Focus, text insertion point, and selection attributes that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through the use of assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.13 Modification of Focus Cursor. Focus, text insertion point, and selection attributes that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through the use of assistive technology.

Criteria text: 502.3.14 Event Notification. Notification of events relevant to user interactions, including but not limited to, changes in the component’s state(s), value, name, description, or boundary, shall be available to assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.14 Event Notification. Notification of events relevant to user interactions, including but not limited to, changes in the component’s state(s), value, name, description, or boundary, shall be available to assistive technology.

502.4 Platforms and platform software shall conform to the requirements in ANSI/HFES 200.2, Human Factors Engineering of Software User Interfaces — Part 2: Accessibility (2008) (incorporated by reference, see 702.4.1) listed below: A. Section 9.3.3 E

Criteria text: 503 Applications
Truncated Criteria: 503 Applications

Criteria text:
503.2 User Preferences. Applications shall permit user preferences from platform settings for color, contrast, font type, font size, and focus cursor.

EXCEPTION: Applications that are designed to be isolated from their underlying platform software, including Web applications, shall not be required to conform to 503.2.
Truncated Criteria: 503.2 User Preferences. Applications shall permit user preferences from platform settings for color, contrast, font type, font size, and focus cursor.  EXCEPTION: Applications that are designed to be isolated from their underlying platform software,

Criteria text: 503.3 Alternative User Interfaces. Where an application provides an alternative user interface that functions as assistive technology, the application shall use platform and other industry standard accessibility services.
Truncated Criteria: 503.3 Alternative User Interfaces. Where an application provides an alternative user interface that functions as assistive technology, the application shall use platform and other industry standard accessibility services.

VPAT Alignment: 503.4 User Controls for Captions and Audio Description
Criteria text: 503.4 User Controls for Captions and Audio Description
Truncated Criteria: 503.4 User Controls for Captions and Audio Description

Criteria text: 503.4.1 Caption Controls. Where user controls are provided for volume adjustment, ICT shall provide user controls for the selection of captions at the same menu level as the user controls for volume or program selection.
Truncated Criteria: 503.4.1 Caption Controls. Where user controls are provided for volume adjustment, ICT shall provide user controls for the selection of captions at the same menu level as the user controls for volume or program selection.

Criteria text: 503.4.2 Audio Description Controls. Where user controls are provided for program selection, ICT shall provide user controls for the selection of audio descriptions at the same menu level as the user controls for volume or program selection.
Truncated Criteria: 503.4.2 Audio Description Controls. Where user controls are provided for program selection, ICT shall provide user controls for the selection of audio descriptions at the same menu level as the user controls for volume or program selection.

601.1 Scope

Truncated Criteria: 602 Support Documentation

Criteria text: 602.2 Accessibility and Compatibility Features. Documentation shall list and explain how to use the accessibility and compatibility features required by Chapters 4 and 5. Documentation shall include accessibility features that are built-in and accessibility features that provide compatibility with assistive technology.
Truncated Criteria: 602.2 Accessibility and Compatibility Features. Documentation shall list and explain how to use the accessibility and compatibility features required by Chapters 4 and 5. Documentation shall include accessibility features that are built-in and access

Criteria text: 602.3 Electronic Support Documentation. Documentation in electronic format, including Web-based self-service support, shall conform to Level A and Level AA Success Criteria and Conformance Requirements in WCAG 2.0 (incorporated by reference, see 702.10.1).
Truncated Criteria: 602.3 Electronic Support Documentation. Documentation in electronic format, including Web-based self-service support, shall conform to Level A and Level AA Success Criteria and Conformance Requirements in WCAG 2.0 (incorporated by reference, see 702.

VPAT Alignment: 602.4 Alternate Formats for Non-Electronic Support Documentation
TooSmallTrun: 602.4 Alternate Formats for Non-Electronic Support Documentation
Criteria text: 602.4 Alternate Formats for Non-Electronic Support Documentation. Where support documentation is only provided in non-electronic formats, alternate formats usable by individuals with disabilities shall be provided upon request.
Truncated Criteria: 602.4 Alternate Formats for Non-Electronic Support Documentation. Where support documentation is only provided in non-electronic formats, alternate formats usable by individuals with disabilities shall be provided upon request.

Criteria text: 603 Support Services
Truncated Criteria: 603 Support Services

VPAT Alignment: 603.2 Information on Accessibility and Compatibility Features
TooSmallTrun: 603.2 Information on Accessibility and Compatibility Features
Criteria text: 603.2 Information on Accessibility and Compatibility Features. ICT support services shall include information on the accessibility and compatibility features required by 602.2.
Truncated Criteria: 603.2 Information on Accessibility and Compatibility Features. ICT support services shall include information on the accessibility and compatibility features required by 602.2.

Criteria text: 603.3 Accommodation of Communication Needs. Support services shall be provided directly to the user or through a referral to a point of contact. Such ICT support services shall accommodate the communication needs of individuals with disabilities.
Truncated Criteria: 603.3 Accommodation of Communication Needs. Support services shall be provided directly to the user or through a referral to a point of contact. Such ICT support services shall accommodate the communication needs of individuals with disabilities.

Criteria text: Criteria
302.1 Without Vision. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user vision.
Truncated Criteria: 302.1 Without Vision. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user vision.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is keyboard and assistive technology accessible. Elements placed within it should natively receive focus.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 302.2 With Limited Vision. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that enables users to make use of limited vision.
Truncated Criteria: 302.2 With Limited Vision. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that enables users to make use of limited vision.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is available for alternative mode of operation and responsively resize to 400%.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 302.3 Without Perception of Color. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one visual mode of operation that does not require user perception of color.
Truncated Criteria: 302.3 Without Perception of Color. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one visual mode of operation that does not require user perception of color.
Explanation:
Terra components do not require perception of color to operate. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure color alone is not the only method of conveying information.

Criteria text: 302.4 Without Hearing. Where an audible mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user hearing.
Truncated Criteria: 302.4 Without Hearing. Where an audible mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user hearing.
Explanation:
Product will create a meaningful experience for someone who is deaf because the product doesn't have any sound. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if audio is added to the product.

Criteria text: 302.5 With Limited Hearing. Where an audible mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that enables users to make use of limited hearing.
Truncated Criteria: 302.5 With Limited Hearing. Where an audible mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that enables users to make use of limited hearing.
Explanation:
Product will create a meaningful experience for someone who is hard of hearing because the product doesn't have any sound. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if audio is added to the product.

Criteria text: 302.6 Without Speech. Where speech is used for input, control, or operation, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user speech.
Truncated Criteria: 302.6 Without Speech. Where speech is used for input, control, or operation, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user speech.
Explanation: Product will create a meaningful experience for someone who has a speech impediment or lack of speech because the product doesn't require speech.

Criteria text: 302.7 With Limited Manipulation. Where a manual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require fine motor control or simultaneous manual operations.
Truncated Criteria: 302.7 With Limited Manipulation. Where a manual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require fine motor control or simultaneous manual operations.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer Field can be used to create a meaningful experience for people with limited manipulation because they provide standard size click targets and do not require fine motor skills or simultaneous keyboard commands.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 302.8 With Limited Reach and Strength. Where a manual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that is operable with limited reach and limited strength.
Truncated Criteria: 302.8 With Limited Reach and Strength. Where a manual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that is operable with limited reach and limited strength.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer Field can be used to create a meaningful experience for people with limited reach and strength because they support assistive technology, and do not rely on a user's reach or specific strength to operate.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

VPAT Alignment: 302.9 With Limited Language, Cognitive, and Learning Abilities
TooSmallTrun: 302.9 With Limited Language, Cognitive, and Learning Abilities
Criteria text: 302.9 With Limited Language, Cognitive, and Learning Abilities. ICT shall provide features making its use by individuals with limited cognitive, language, and learning abilities simpler and easier.
Truncated Criteria: 302.9 With Limited Language, Cognitive, and Learning Abilities. ICT shall provide features making its use by individuals with limited cognitive, language, and learning abilities simpler and easier.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer Field can be used by people with limited language, cognitive, and learning abilities when consuming teams implement with proper labels, instructions, and following best practice.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: Chapter 4: Hardware
Truncated Criteria: 402 Closed Functionality

Criteria text: Criteria

4.2.1 Usage without vision Where ICT provides visual modes of operation, some users need ICT to provide at least one mode of operation that does not require vision. NOTE: Audio and tactile user interfaces may contribute to meeting this clause.
Truncated Criteria: 302.1 Without Vision. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user vision.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is keyboard and assistive technology accessible. Elements placed within it should natively receive focus.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 4.2.2 Usage with limited vision Where ICT provides visual modes of operation, some users will need the ICT to provide features that enable users to make better use of their limited vision.
Truncated Criteria: 302.2 With Limited Vision. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that enables users to make use of limited vision.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer is available for alternative mode of operation and responsively resize to 400%.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 4.2.3 Usage without perception of colour Where ICT provides visual modes of operation, some users will need the ICT to provide a visual mode of operation that does not require user perception of colour.
Truncated Criteria: 302.3 Without Perception of Color. Where a visual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one visual mode of operation that does not require user perception of color.
Explanation:
Terra components do not require perception of color to operate. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure color alone is not the only method of conveying information.

Criteria text: 4.2.4 Usage without hearing Where ICT provides auditory modes of operation, some users need ICT to provide at least one mode of operation that does not require hearing.
Truncated Criteria: 302.4 Without Hearing. Where an audible mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user hearing.
Explanation:
Product will create a meaningful experience for someone who is deaf because the product doesn't have any sound. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if audio is added to the product.

Criteria text: 4.2.5 Usage with limited hearing Where ICT provides auditory modes of operation, some users will need the ICT to provide enhanced audio features.
Truncated Criteria: 302.5 With Limited Hearing. Where an audible mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that enables users to make use of limited hearing.
Explanation:
Product will create a meaningful experience for someone who is hard of hearing because the product doesn't have any sound. 

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if audio is added to the product.

Criteria text: 4.2.6 Usage without vocal capability Where ICT requires vocal input from users, some users will need the ICT to provide at least one mode of operation that does not require them to generate vocal output.
Truncated Criteria: 302.6 Without Speech. Where speech is used for input, control, or operation, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require user speech.
Explanation: Product will create a meaningful experience for someone who has a speech impediment or lack of speech because the product doesn't require speech.

VPAT Alignment: 4.2.7 Usage with limited manipulation or strength
Criteria text: 4.2.7 Usage with limited manipulation or strength Where ICT requires manual actions, some users will need the ICT to provide features that enable users to make use of the ICT through alternative actions not requiring manipulation or hand strength.
Truncated Criteria: 302.7 With Limited Manipulation. Where a manual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that does not require fine motor control or simultaneous manual operations.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer Field can be used to create a meaningful experience for people with limited manipulation because they provide standard size click targets and do not require fine motor skills or simultaneous keyboard commands.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 4.2.8 Usage with limited reach Where ICT products are free-standing or installed, the operational elements will need to be within reach of all users.
Truncated Criteria: 302.8 With Limited Reach and Strength. Where a manual mode of operation is provided, ICT shall provide at least one mode of operation that is operable with limited reach and limited strength.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer Field can be used to create a meaningful experience for people with limited reach and strength because they support assistive technology, and do not rely on a user's reach or specific strength to operate.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 4.2.9 Minimize photosensitive seizure triggers Where ICT provides visual modes of operation, some users need ICT to provide at least one mode of operation that minimizes the potential for triggering photosensitive seizures.
Truncated Criteria: 2.3.1 Three Flashes or Below Threshold: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds. (Level A)  Note: Since any content that does not
Explanation:
Product contains no flashing or flickering that would cause seizures or migraines.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met if media is added to the product.

Criteria text: 4.2.10 Usage with limited cognition Some users will need the ICT to provide features that make it simpler and easier to use.
Truncated Criteria: 302.9 With Limited Language, Cognitive, and Learning Abilities. ICT shall provide features making its use by individuals with limited cognitive, language, and learning abilities simpler and easier.
Explanation:
Terra Action Footer Field can be used by people with limited language, cognitive, and learning abilities when consuming teams implement with proper labels, instructions, and following best practice.

Implementing team(s) must ensure this criterion is met.

Criteria text: 4.2.11 Privacy Where ICT provides features that are provided for accessibility, some users will need their privacy to be maintained when using those ICT features that are provided for accessibility.
Truncated Criteria: 4.2.11 Privacy Where ICT provides features that are provided for accessibility, some users will need their privacy to be maintained when using those ICT features that are provided for accessibility.
Explanation: Product does not compromise patient or user privacy.

EN7. ICT with video capabilities

Criteria text: 7.1 Caption processing technology
Truncated Criteria: 7.1 Caption processing technology

Criteria text: 7.1.1 Captioning playback
Truncated Criteria:
7.1.1 Captioning playback Where ICT displays video with synchronized audio, it shall have a mode of operation to display the available captions.
Where closed captions are provided as part of the content, the ICT shall allow the user to choose to disp

Criteria text: 7.1.2 Captioning synchronization
Truncated Criteria: 7.1.2 Captioning synchronization Where ICT displays captions, the mechanism to display captions shall preserve synchronization between the audio and the corresponding captions.

Criteria text: 7.1.3 Preservation of captioning
Truncated Criteria: 7.1.3 Preservation of captioning Where ICT transmits, converts or records video with synchronized audio, it shall preserve caption data such that it can be displayed in a manner consistent with clauses 7.1.1 and 7.1.2. Additional presentational aspec

Criteria text: 7.2.1 Audio description playback
Truncated Criteria: 7.2.1 Audio description playback Where ICT displays video with synchronized audio, it shall provide a mechanism to select and play available audio description to the default audio channel. Where video technologies do not have explicit and separate me

Criteria text: 7.2.2 Audio description synchronization
Truncated Criteria: 7.2.2 Audio description synchronization Where ICT has a mechanism to play audio description, it shall preserve the synchronization between the audio/visual content and the corresponding audio description.

Criteria text: 7.2.3 Preservation of audio description
Truncated Criteria: 7.2.3 Preservation of audio description Where ICT transmits, converts, or records video with synchronized audio, it shall preserve audio description data such that it can be played in a manner consistent with clauses 7.2.1 and 7.2.2.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.3 Use of accessibility services
Truncated Criteria: 602.2 Accessibility and Compatibility Features. Documentation shall list and explain how to use the accessibility and compatibility features required by Chapters 4 and 5. Documentation shall include accessibility features that are built-in and access

Criteria text: 11.3.2.4 Assistive technology
Truncated Criteria: 502.4 Platforms and platform software shall conform to the requirements in ANSI/HFES 200.2, Human Factors Engineering of Software User Interfaces — Part 2: Accessibility (2008) (incorporated by reference, see 702.4.1) listed below: A. Section 9.3.3 E

Criteria text: 11.3.2.5 Object information
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.1 Object Information. The object role, state(s), properties, boundary, name, and description shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.6 Row, column, and headers
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.3 Row, Column, and Headers. If an object is in a data table, the occupied rows and columns, and any headers associated with those rows or columns, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.7 Values
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.4 Values. Any current value(s), and any set or range of allowable values associated with an object, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.8 Label relationships
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.6 Label Relationships. Any relationship that a component has as a label for another component, or of being labeled by another component, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.9 Parent-child relationships
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.7 Hierarchical Relationships. Any hierarchical (parent-child) relationship that a component has as a container for, or being contained by, another component shall be programmatically determinable.
502.3.8 Text. The content of text objects, text attributes, and the boundary of text rendered to the screen, shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.11 List of available actions
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.10 List of Actions. A list of all actions that can be executed on an object shall be programmatically determinable.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.12 Execution of available actions
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.11 Actions on Objects. Applications shall allow assistive technology to programmatically execute available actions on objects.

VPAT Alignment: 11.5.2.13 Tracking of focus and selection attributes
TooSmallTrun: 11.5.2.13 Tracking of focus and selection attributes
Criteria text: 11.3.2.13 Tracking of focus and selection attributes
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.12 Focus Cursor. Applications shall expose information and mechanisms necessary to track focus, text insertion point, and selection attributes of user interface components.

VPAT Alignment: 11.5.2.14 Modification of focus and selection attributes
TooSmallTrun: 11.5.2.14 Modification of focus and selection attributes
Criteria text: 11.3.2.14 Modification of focus and selection attributes
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.13 Modification of Focus Cursor. Focus, text insertion point, and selection attributes that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through the use of assistive technology.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.15 Change notification
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.14 Event Notification. Notification of events relevant to user interactions, including but not limited to, changes in the component’s state(s), value, name, description, or boundary, shall be available to assistive technology.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.16 Modifications of states and properties
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.2 Modification of Object Information. States and properties that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.

Criteria text: 11.3.2.17 Modifications of values and text
Truncated Criteria: 502.3.9 Modification of Text. Text that can be set by the user shall be capable of being set programmatically, including through assistive technology.

Criteria text: 11.4 Documented accessibility usage
Truncated Criteria: 11.6 Documented accessibility usage

Criteria text: 11.4.1 User control of accessibility features
Truncated Criteria: 502.2.1 User Control of Accessibility Features. Platform software shall provide user control over platform features that are defined in the platform documentation as accessibility features.

Criteria text: 11.4.2 No disruption of accessibility features
Truncated Criteria: 502.2.2 No Disruption of Accessibility Features. Software shall not disrupt platform features that are defined in the platform documentation as accessibility features.

Criteria text: 11.5 User preferences
Truncated Criteria: 503.2 User Preferences. Applications shall permit user preferences from platform settings for color, contrast, font type, font size, and focus cursor.  EXCEPTION: Applications that are designed to be isolated from their underlying platform software,

Truncated Criteria: 603.2 Information on Accessibility and Compatibility Features. ICT support services shall include information on the accessibility and compatibility features required by 602.2.

Criteria text: 12.2.3 Effective communication
Truncated Criteria: 603.3 Accommodation of Communication Needs. Support services shall be provided directly to the user or through a referral to a point of contact. Such ICT support services shall accommodate the communication needs of individuals with disabilities.
